reviewText: the last of a 3 part set of the serials. great movie to have. 1st serial frank and jesse james, 2nd jesse james rides again. a must to buy these. a bonus clayton moore aka the lone ranger if your a fan. he's in the first 2.

Republic Pictures present "JAMES BROTHERS OF MISSOURI" (1949) (167 mins/B&W) (Dolby digitally remastered) --- is a 12-Chapter Republic Movie Serial starring Keith Richards, Robert Bice, Noel Neill, Roy Barcroft & Patricia Knox, relive those thrilling days week after week venue brought you to the theater, as you were mesmerized in your seat waiting for the final chapter ... exciting action within 12 episodes from the Republic Serials department, released in October 4, 1949, the plot line follows the path of an effort to reform, the James Brothers try to settle down and live within the law. But soon the boys are back in action trying to defend themselves in a turbulent battle that threatens their very lives, "The James Brothers of Missouri" was the third of three serials based on the Jesse James character, produced by Republic Pictures in the late 40s ... Roy Barcroft and Lane Bradford.shine as the badmen ... the once fabulous Republic Studio serial machine turned out true masterpieces of action during the late 30s and early 40s ... remember this serial from the Saturday double features at our neighborhood theater ... 12 breathtaking chapters come across with all the gusto Republic Studios has to offer.

Under Fred C. Brannon (Director), Franklin Adreon (Associate Producer), Royal K. Cole (Screenwriter), William Lively (Screenwriter), Sol Shor (Screenwriter), Stanley Wilson (Original Score), Ellis W. Carter (Cinematographer), Cliff Bell Sr.(Editor), Sam Starr (Editor) ------ the cast includes Keith Richards (Jesse James), Robert Bice (Frank James), Noel Neill (Peg Royer), Roy Barcroft (Ace Marlin), Patricia Knox (Belle Calhoun), Lane Bradford (Monk Tucker), Gene Roth (Marshal Rand), John Hamilton (Lon Royer), Edmund Cobb (The Sheriff), Hank Patterson (Walller, old-timer), Dale Van Sickel (Harry Sharkey aka Henry Simpson), Tom Steele (Lanky Royer Employee/Lanky Thug Guarding Simpson/Thug Guarding Wagon), Lee Roberts ('Brandy' Jones), Wade Ray (Deputy Enforcing Toll), Nolan Leary ('Pop' Keever), John Crawford (Mr. Carson), Art Dillard (Blears/Townsman 1), Al Ferguson (Heavy 1), Duke Green (Henchman), Cactus Mack (Heavy 2), Marshall Reed (Cave Guard), David Sharpe (Bailey, mine thug), Duke Taylor (Flint/Pete), Ken Terrell (Arsonist/Wagon Decoy), Robert J. Wilke (Townsman 2) ... great stunt work by the Republic stunt personnel David Sharpe, Tom Steele and Dale Van Sickel --- don't leave the theater until the final chapter ... another winner from the vaults of Republic Serials --- this is a must watch for the serial buffs in all of us.

BIOS:

1. Keith Richards

Date of birth:  18 July 1915 - Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Date of death:  23 March 1987 - Los Angeles, California

2.  Robert Bice

Date of birth:  4 March 1914 - Dallas, Texas

Date of death:  8 January 1968 - Los Angeles, California

3. Fred C. Brannon (Director) ("The Black Widow" (1947)/Serial)

Date of birth: 26 April 1901 - Louisiana, USA

Date of death: 6 April 1953 - Los Angeles, California

Second special footnote, "King of the Rocket Men" has a truly amazing mid-air chase in one of its early

chapters, ending with a startlingly realistic piece of stunt work as the rocket man flies in pursuit of

a plane, Brannon also directed episodes of the "Commando Cody" (1953) television series.

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author: Trail Talk), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author: The Real Bob Steele) as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns ... order your copy now from Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out VCI Entertainment where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns and Serials --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 167 mins on VHS ~ Republic Video ~ (5/30/1995)

Although the cliffhangers consist of way too many hero-wakes-up-and-rolls-out-of-the-way situations, this is a surprisingly good Western.  In many ways it has more the feel of a feature B-Western than a serial.

The late 1940's was a period of decline in the serial genre, and perhaps Republic was reaching when they felt the need to attract an audience by making serials about Jesse and Frank James.  They couldn't very well have criminals as heroes, so they made them reform and help others face down the bad guys--in fact this was the third and last of the Jesse James serials.  Keith Richards and Robert Bice were bit players in lots of B-Westerns, surprisingly elevated to star status as the leads.  They underplay their parts admirably, and though they didn't have much of a pedigree they seem to develop a little charisma as they go along.  Keith Richards especially, as Jesse, grows into the part as the plot develops.

Roy Barcroft, perhaps the most beloved B-Western baddie of all time, is at his best here.  Noel Neill's cutesy presence worked well when she played Lois Lane in the "Superman" serials, but she doesn't seem quite right in the role of a frontier heroine.  Dale Van Sickle and Tom Steele were given credits for roles as minor thugs, so you can bet they did a lot of the stunt doubling--as did David Sharpe, though uncredited.

The plot is a rather interesting treatment of the James Brothers' attempts to go straight.  It gets better as it goes along, and the last few chapters are actually rather exciting.  I steadily increased my rating as the chapters proceeded.  By the end, I found myself enjoying it far more than I had expected to.
